Article.title: David Cameron throws his weight behind FA bid to unseat FIFA's Sepp Blatter
Article.Description: The Prime Minister said he supported the Culture and Sports Secretary John Whittingdale after he told MPs the 79-year-old Swiss chief needed to resign as head of the 'corrupt organisation'.
Article.MainBody:
Share 86 shares Asked if the Prime Minister believed the next World Cup should be staged in England, the spokesman said: 'I understand many England fans were disappointed that England's bid hadn't been successful. 'You know that the Prime Minister was one of them. He was out there trying to get a successful England bid at that time. But, the focus now is both the investigations and reform of Fifa.' It came after Mr Whittingdale welcomed the investigations into the allegations of bribery and corruption in the Commons this morning. He said: 'It is important that other sponsors reflect on their links to Fifa and consider following Visa's lead.' Mr Whittingdale said the Government fully supported the English Football Association's position that significant and wide-ranging reforms are urgently needed at the top of Fifa, including 'a change in its leadership' The Prime Minister's official spokesman this morning confirmed Mr Cameron was 'squarely behind' the FA's bid to get rid of Mr Blatter Sports Minister Tracey Crouch will write to her European counterparts setting out the UK's concerns and seeking their support for change, Mr Whittingdale said. Replying to an urgent question, he said: 'The arrests that took place in Zurich yesterday, along with the statements released by the US department of justice and the Swiss attorney general, were shocking in both their scale and scope - however, they were also far from surprising. 'Anyone who has spent any time looking at Fifa ... will know that this is merely the latest sorry episode, which suggests that Fifa is a deeply flawed and corrupt organisation. 'These revelations have shown how important it is for sports bodies to uphold the highest standards of governance, transparency and accountability. 'That is what we ask and expect of all our own domestic sports bodies in the UK, international bodies should be no different and that is particularly true for an organisation like Fifa - an organisation that should be the guardian of the world's most popular sport, not one whose members seek to profit personally from the passion of the game's fans.' Mr Cameron said he supported Mr Blatter's rival for football's too job Prince Ali bin al-Hussein (pictured) He went on: 'Football is the world's game and it is our national game. 'It is a fundamental part of British life and culture yet these revelations have dragged the game's reputation into the mud. 'The time has clearly come for change and we will offer whatever support is necessary to the Football Association to see that change realised.' Tory Stephen Phillips, who asked the urgent question, called for the Government and FA to take steps to recover the 19 million 'wasted' on England's 2018 World Cup bid, which could have gone to grassroots football. He also called for Fifa to reopen the bidding processes for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, which are due to be held in Russia and Qatar. The MP for Sleaford and North Hykeham said: 'You will know from your work on the select committee in the last parliament that the English FA made an unsuccessful bid for the 2018 World Cup which cost something in the region of 19 million. 'That bid of course had the backing of His Royal Highness Prince William and of David Beckham amongst others, but it received only two votes. 'What investigations do you now intend to carry out to examine whether that bid failed due to bribery and corruption on the part of Fifa officials? 'Will you discuss with the English Football Association the steps which can now be taken to recover the 19 million which was wasted and which could have gone on grassroots community football in this country? 'Can you say what steps the Government will now take to recover any money which it wasted on the failed bid? 'And do you think, as many members no doubt do, that the bidding process for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups should now be reopened?' Mr Whittingdale said he would be speaking to FA chairman Greg Dyke later today and said he was pleased the home nations associations had joined with Uefa in calling for the Fifa presidential election to be postponed.

Article.title: ISIS 'destroys' lion god statue in captured Palmyra in Syria
Article.Description: Following their capture of Palmyra last Thursday, ISIS militants are understood to have won the support of the local population by promising not to destroy the city's famous monuments.
Article.MainBody:
Share this article Share The act of destroying the statue came just days after ISIS gathered Palmyra's citizens together and publicly promised not to bulldoze the city's ancient buildings, as they previously did in Nimrod. 'As for the historical monuments, we will not touch it with our bulldozers as some tend to believe,' ISIS commander Abu Leith was quoted as saying on a local radio broadcast. However the promise did come with a get-out clause, as the depraved fighters insisted they would 'pulverise' any statues they discovered in the city that the believed citizens secretly prayed to. The interior ofPalmyra's ancient Roman amphitheatre is seen in these pictures released by ISIS supporters Destroyed:This photograph shows rubble in Palmyra's streets caused by Syrian regime airstrikes on ISIS Frontline of fighting: The buildings are said to have been reduced to rubble by Syrian regime warplanes The lion statue in Palmyra dates from the first century AD and stood outside the city's famous Temple of Bel. The statue was dedicated to the pre-Islamic Arabian goddess Al-Lat, who was one of the three chief goddesses of Mecca along with Manat and al-Uzza. The Temple of Bel itself was built in 32 AD - six hundred years before the arrival of Islam in Syria - and was dedicated to the Semitic god Bel - who was worshiped by Palmyra citizens along withthe lunar god Aglibol and the sun god Yarhibol. Since ISIS seized control of Palmyra, the temple and its surrounding area have been appropriated by ISIS militants, who are said to be using it as a military base. Locals who preserved the site for the last 1,900 years are now said to be banned from entering the area unless the are willing to sign up to become ISIS jihadis. Rubble: Debris from badly damaged and destroyed ancient buildings are seen littering the streets of Palmyra Palmyra damaged by Syrian air force strikes ISIS is accused of executing hundreds of people in and around Palmyra since it swept into the oasis city last week after a lightning advance across the desert from its stronghold in the Euphrates Valley to the east. But they have also released propaganda images showing the terrorists releasing prisoners from Tadmor Prison - with the convicts seen embracing one another in the streets after being freed. Yesterday the extremists 'called people to watch' as they executed 20 local men in a Roman ampitheatre in the ancient Syrian city. The men were shot dead in the restored ruin, which had been used for an annual festival in the city, in front of the crowd. The murdered locals were accused of being government supporters, according to a report from theSyrian Observatory for Human Rights. 'IS executed 20 men by firing on them in front of a crowd gathered in Palmyra's Roman theatre, after accusing them of fighting for the Syrian regime,' Rami Abdel Rahman, head of the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, told AFP. He added: 'IS gathered a lot of people there on purpose, to show their force on the ground.' Under threat: Many of the ancient Roman buildings in Palmyra have been standing for thousands of years Chilling: The short video released by the local pro-ISIS media company Aamaq News shows thick black smoke rising over Roman ruins that have stood for thousands of years in the central Syrian desert city Sickening: A picture sent by activists to a Western journalist shows a row of men lying in pools of blood in a street in Palmyra last week. At least four of the men had been decapitated
Road to Palmyra deserted but inside the city people celebrate This morning the European Union added a high-ranking Syrian military official to its sanctions list, as it extended measures against supporters of President Bashar al-Assad for another year. The EU began imposing asset freezes and travel bans on Assad and his supporters in 2011 to protest a government crackdown on Assad's opponents. With Syria's civil war now in its fifth year, the sanctions list has grown to more than 200 people and 70 organisations. EU governments decided to extend the sanctions another year and add one person to the list - a high-ranking military official the EU accused of being 'responsible for repression and violence against the civilian population in Damascus and Damascus countryside.' The name of the official, who will be subject to an asset freeze and ban on travelling to the EU, will not be made public until details of the sanctions are published in the EU's Official Journal on Friday. Other EU sanctions on Syria include restrictions on exporting equipment that might be used for internal repression and a ban on importing oil from Syria. ISIS MILITANTS RELEASE CHILLING PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE HORRIFIC CONDITIONS INSIDE PALMYRA PRISON WHERE ASSAD'S SOLDIERS ONCE TORTURED THOUSANDS Militants fighting for the Islamic State have released images of the horrific conditions in which those opposed to the Assad regime were kept at the notorious Tadmor Prison in Syria. Following their capture of Palmyra last Thursday, ISIS jihadis released dozens of prisoners from the ancient city's jail, which is famous for the torture and summary execution of those held there. Images of the now empty prison show tiny windowless jail cells where those accused of committing crimes were held in total darkness once the huge steel doors slammed shut. Terrible conditions: Images of the now empty prison show tiny windowless jail cells where those accused of committing crimes were held in total darkness once the huge steel doors slammed shut Horror: The new photographs reveal how conditions at the prison have hardly changed in decades - with prisoners held in disturbingly small cells with cold stone walls with no lighting or bedding The only semblance of a toilet in the cells is a small hole in the floor, and even the corridors and communal areas are seen covered in mould - suggesting the building is riddled with damp and unlikely to have any sort of heating during Syria's long and bitterly cold winters. Although the images of the now-deserted jail were released as part of a propaganda exercise by ISIS terrorists, they show a building notorious for the guards' brutal treatment of prisoners and even a state-sponsored massacre of those held there in the early 1980s. Governor's office:Tadmor Prison was the scene of a horrific massacre on June 27, 1980 following an Islamist Muslim Brotherhood assassination attempt on the then president, Hafez al-Assad Jail break: This picture shared on several pro-ISIS Twitter account claims to show prisoners celebrating with their liberators after being freed from the notorious Tadmur prison by ISIS fighters in Palmyra Chilling footage shows conditions inside Palmyra prison The new photographs reveal how conditions at the prison have hardly changed in decades - with prisoners held in disturbingly small cells with cold stone walls with no lighting or bedding. The corridors of the prison are crumbling and the entire building looks as thought it was abandoned decades years ago.It is hard to believe the prison was crammed full of prisoners just last week. Tadmor Prison was the scene of a horrific massacre on June 27, 1980 following an Islamist Muslim Brotherhood assassination attempt on the then president, Hafez al-Assad. The day after the attempted attack, the president's brother Rifaat al-Assad ordered the country's Defence Brigades to enter the jail and butcher the prisoners. Article.title: HERON flies into Number 10 and perches on Downing Street door
Article.Description: The bird took refuge in the Prime Minister's official residence this afternoon - walking around the hallway and sitting on the front door - after being frightened by a nearby crow.
Article.MainBody: comments No amount of security measures was able to keep an uninvited visitor out of Downing Street this afternoon - after a heron flew into Number 10. The bird perched itself on top of the Prime Minister's front door, after seeking refuge in the hallway from the unwanted attentions of a crow. It was photographed by an astonished Conservative aide who admitted he was glad that it had flown away - because it is a bad omen in Greek mythology. Scroll down for video No amount of security measures was able to keep an uninvited visitor out of Downing Street this afternoon - after a heron ruffled flew into Number 10 The heron perched itself on top of the Prime Minister's famous front door, after seeking refuge in the hallway from the unwanted attentions of a crow The bird was frightened by a nearby crow into taking shelter in the Prime Ministers official residence. Number 10 staff rushed to close their doors to stop the bird getting deeper into building. The heron was only there for a few minutes before hopping out of the door and flying off again. It was only able to enter after the door to Number 10 was left open, as it occasionally is on hot days. But despite herons being nicknamed the 'shitepoke' in some quarters for their usual reaction to being disturbed, the carefully-maintained shiny black paintwork was not sullied. 'It did not lose its deposit,' joked long-serving Scottish affairs special adviser Ramsay Jones, whose snap of the incident quickly became a hot talking point on social media. 'I was just coming in and the bird was already inside the building, just sitting quietly in the corner,' he said. 'It then decided to fly up on top of the door before it hopped off.' Article.title: Case of Lindsay Lohan's alleged stalker collapses
Article.Description: Lindsay Lohan (pictured) failed to show up at Westminster Magistrates Court to give evidence against Daniel Vorderwulbecke. He was said to have sent her more than 1,000 messages.
Article.MainBody: Share this article Share Vorderwulbecke was accused of bombarding Lohan with more than 1,000 messages and attacking a bouncer who barred him from seeing her rehearse for David Mamet's satire Speed-The-Plow. A charge of assault against Vorderwulbecke, who allegedly punched a doorman who prevented him reaching the actressat London's Playhouse Theatre, was dropped. But he still faces two charges of criminal damage and one of harassment and that trial is still going ahead. Stalking charges against 37-year-old alleged stalker Daniel Vorderwulbecke were dropped, picturedat Westminster Magistrates Court It was claimed that the 37-year-old, who goes by names including King Lionheart and DJ Dan Cortez, allegedly sent Miss Lohan thousands of text messages. Mr Bowyer told the court: 'We became aware 10 days ago that Lindsay Lohan was required to return to the US to complete a community service order. 'We were informed by the US authorities she was due to complete the order yesterday and was at liberty to leave the US at 9pm our time yesterday. 'Bearing in mind we had two days set aside for trial, we very much hoped she would take a flight today in order to give evidence tomorrow. 'She has chosen not to do so and she will not be in the jurisdiction to give evidence tomorrow. Having given the matter anxious consideration and consideration within the highest level of the CPS the two charges (of stalking) will not be proceeding. 'The other three charges we will be proceeding with.' But a spokeswoman for Lohan claimed that the actress was not able to fly back for the hearing today because an official decision regarding her reckless driving case was made in an LA court on the same day. She reportedly worked eight hours a day for more than two weeks in order to fulfill the requirements ahead of her Thursday deadline. The defendant allegedly believes he is married to Miss Lohan and claims to speak to the actress every day personally and through social media. Vorderwulbecke was arrested near the Playhouse Theatre in August last year after Chiltern Firehouse staff member Lauren Pearce complained he had been bombarding them with abusive emails. The defendant was interviewed by police and bailed on the conditions that he would not contact Miss Lohan or Ms Pearce, not enter the City of Westminster and surrender his passport. But he breached his bail conditions the next day by asking staff at the theatre to pass a note to the actress. Police were called to the Playhouse Theatre again on September 8 where Vorderwulbecke had allegedly caused damage to a metal cigarette bin valued at 100. He also allegedly damaged the back door of the Chiltern Firehouse when he failed to see her. Three days later he allegedly assaulted security worker Cameron Ashrat. A former DJ, Vorderwulbecke, who also calls himself Dan Cortez, lists himself on Facebook as being married to Lindsay Lohan. The Freaky Friday actress was doing 125 hours of community service for committing reckless driving in 2012. Prosecutor Martyn Bowyer today told the court the star had 'chosen' not to attend, meaning the CPS will not be proceeding with the two stalking charges In order to complete her community service obligations, Lindsay worked at three different charitable organisations including the Duffield Children's Center (pictured) Share or comment on this article 167

Article.title: Newborn Arctic wolf's attempts to wrestle its mother delight Czech zoo crowds
Article.Description: Scenes of the just days-old pup rolling around in the dirt as its mother supervises it have proved hugely popular among the crowds at Olomouc Zoo in the Czech Republic.
Article.MainBody: Newborn wolf's adorable attempts to wrestle with its mother delight crowds at Czech zoo Newborn Arctic wolf proves a hit among crowds at Czech Republic zoo Adorable pictures of it rolling around with its mother have been released Olomouc Zoo is known for its breeding of baby tigers, lions and wolves Published: 15:14 GMT, 28 May 2015 | Updated: 18:01 GMT, 28 May 2015 29 shares comments A newborn wolf's attempts to cuddle, paw and wrestle with its mother have delighted crowds at a zoo in the Czech Republic. Scenes of the days-old pup rolling around in the dirt as its mother supervises it have proved to be particularly popular among families, who have flocked to see the adorable newborn attraction. Taken at the Olomouc Zoo in the Czech Republic, the baby Arctic wolf is so young it is yet to develop the distinctive white fur like its mother. The Arctic wolf's striking colouring means it is hugely popular in zoos and other animal attractions. They are found in the wild in all areas throughout the far north, but predominately in Alaska, where they have evolved to inhabit some of the most inhospitable conditions on earth. So strong is the bond between a mother wolf and her cub, in the wild she will often regurgitate her food in order to feed her offspring. Olomouc Zoo, located in the country's east, is one of the Czech Republic's largest zoos and is also home to many big cats, including lions and tigers. RELATED ARTICLES

Article.title: Moped criminals remove helmets to force Met police to stop chasing
Article.Description: Criminals using mopeds are using a loophole in London by removing their helmets if being chased because Met Officers have been ordered to stand down in case the robbers are killed or injured.
Article.MainBody:
Share this article Share Mr Durante, who runs Designer Exchange in Knightsbridge, said: 'I find it incredible that they can literally drive off, take their helmets off and the chase has to stop. I don't really understand it. 'I think we have got to try and stop criminals and stop giving them any chance of taking what is not theirs.' Another store owner who has suffered from two-wheeled robbers claimed police had 'gone soft' on crime. The man, who did not wish to be named, said : 'Police should be leaving no stone unturned in catching criminals - including giving chase after a robbery. 'This country is becoming far too much of a "Nanny State" in which police have gone soft on the offenders they are meant to be targeting. 'In any case, it is a criminal offence to ride without a crash helmet.' The rules were changed following the death of Reece Leon Robinson-Webber, left, who died in August 2008 The Yard revealed to the BBC this week that some suspects take off their helmets when riding away from officers in pursuit. But Detective Superintendent Raffaele D'Orsi strongly defended the police strategy. He said: 'We have a moral duty and actually a mandate as police officers to protect the public. That includes offenders who are trying to escape from us. REECE LEON ROBINSON-WEBBER Police tried to pull over Reece Robinson-Webber after receiving a call in Streatham, South London The 15-year-old refused to stop and tried to escape on his moped Officers gave chase and the youngster mounted the kerb, lost control and crashed his bike. Chasing police tried to offer CPR, but Mr Robinson-Webber was too badly injured An IPCC investigation cleared officers of any wrongdoing, but found fault with the Met's policy with dealing with motorcycle pursuits 'We have to mitigate the risk so, if an offender is not wearing a helmet, that will be factored in.' A Freedom of Information request by the BBC revealed there were 1,240 crimes in London involving suspects on mopeds or motorbikes last year. The strategy was developed following the death of moped rider Reece Leon Robinson-Webber, 15, from Streatham. He was killed in West Norwood, Lambeth during a police chase in August 2008. The Independent Police Complaints Commission then produced a report which said it had 'overall concerns about the standard of training made available to officers and staff in relation to motorcycle pursuits'. Scotland Yard brought in a number of changes following IPCC recommendations.

Article.title: Eight-month-old boy scarred for life after grabbing mother's hair straighteners
Article.Description: Archie Watkins grabbed the cord of the heated styling tool, which landed on his arms and seared through the skin, after he mistook it for a toy at his home in Cwmbran, South Wales.
Article.MainBody: The blister on Archie's arm after he suffered immediate nerve damage 'It all happened so quickly and highlighted just how dangerous today's super-heated hair appliances are.' She put Archie in a cold bath after the shock subsided but took him to hospital to have the burns looked at, where they learnt he had suffered immediate nerve damage. Mrs Watkins and her husband Shaun, an electrician, were told Archie's injury was just shy of third degree burns - similar to suffered in severe fires and war zones. Two years on from the incident, she is now urging other parents to beware of using straighteners of curling tongs near their children after learning that her son will be scarred for life. The young mother is now using a stand to keeps straighteners irons and curling tongs out of the reach of toddlers. She said: 'I can honestly say that had I had one at the time, Archie's accident would not have happened.' His mother, Rebecca Watkins, 25, (pictured with her husband Shaun, left) rushed him to hospital where they found he had suffered immediate nerve damage THE HAIR-RAISING TRUTH ABOUT STRAIGHTENERS: A THIRD OF WOMEN USE THEM AND THE NUMBER OF BURNS HAVE DOUBLED IN RECENT YEARS It is claimed a third of all women and even an astonishing one in five men now own a pair of hair straighteners. And while trichologists warn about the damage they directly cause to the actual hair follicles, little is known about their direct dangers. Previously, straighteners had been steel-plated and took 20 minutes to reach an effective temperature, but now coated in ceramic they can take less than one minute to reach more than 200c. Hair straighteners can get as hot as an iron. So hot, in fact, you could cook your breakfast on them. The Child Accident Prevention Trust (CAPT) and the Electrical Safety Campaign have teamed up to raise awareness of what they can do. There are concerns that hair straightener burns have doubled in recent years. Most injuries occur when crawling babies and toddlers grab at them, step on them, sit on them or pull them down. Hair straighteners can stay hot enough to burn up to 15 minutes after they have been switched off. But most parents dont know just how dangerous they can be. Over a third leave hair straighteners to cool down on the floor, on furniture or over a door handle. CAPT offers advice on its website: capt.org.uk Read more: Share or comment on this article 184

Article.title: Top Gear number plate WASN'T a reference to Falklands War, rules BBC Trust
Article.Description: The show sparked a diplomatic incident in Argentina when its crew drove through the country in a Porsche with the registration number H982 FKL during its Patagonia special.
Article.MainBody: Share this article Share Another complainant accused the BBC of a 'cover-up' and said they needed to see evidence of the purchase of the car to prove the 'amazing coincidence'. But the Trust's complaints and appeals board said there was no evidence 'which demonstrated that the use of the number plate was a deliberate reference to the Falklands War'. The complaint was originally rejected by the BBC Executive but was sent to the Trust on appeal. Clarkson and his colleagues fled the South American country last year when their convoy - which was led by a Porsche bearing the controversial number plate - came under attack. Afterwards producers removed the plate and replaced it with another. Jeremy Clarkson and fellow presenters Richard Hammond (left) and James May (right) pictured in Argentina where their convoy was attacked by locals furious over Clarkson's number plate The Falkland Islands were taken briefly by Argentina during its 1982 invasion which preceded a 74-day war with Britain. The war claimed the lives of 649 Argentinians and 255 Britons. Alicia Castro, the Argentinian ambassador to the UK, demanded an apology from BBC head of television Danny Cohen during a meeting in October last year - which the corporation refused to give. In a letter to Ms Castro, Mr Cohen said the BBC would also go ahead and broadcast the programme - which aired over Christmas. He said: 'We will ensure that these programmes are a fair representation of what took place throughout their stay.' He added: 'I am very aware that some have questioned whether the number plates were in some way a prank. 'I would like to reassure you again that nothing we have seen or read since the team returned supports the view that this was a deliberate act.' Cohen said 'the BBC was disturbed by the violence the team faced during their visit'. Top Gear executive producer Andy Wilman previously denied the number plate was a 'stunt' and presenter Jeremy Clarkson said he was 'shocked' when someone pointed out the link between the number plate and the Falklands War days into filming. Clarkson was dropped from the BBC following a 'fracas' with producer Oisin Tymon over hot food. In March, he was suspended, then dropped, by the BBC following the incident at a hotel in which Tymon suffered swelling and a split lip, requiring him to visit a hospital A&E department. Following an internal investigation, the BBC announced on March 25 that Clarkson's contract on Top Gear would not be renewed.

Article.title: Boy, 5, abandoned at Blair Drummond Safari Park after school trip
Article.Description: Owen Paterson had been on a school outing to Blair Drummond Safari Park along with Pitcorthie Primary and Nursery, Fife. But when coaches returned to the school he was nowhere to be found.
Article.MainBody: comments Owen Paterson, 5, was left behind after a school outing to Blair Drummond Safari Park The furious family of a five-year-old boy have hit out at 'shambolic' teachers after he was accidentally left at a safari park on his own for two hours following a school trip. Owen Paterson had been on a school outing to Blair Drummond Safari Park along with 300 other pupils from Pitcorthie Primary and Nursery, Fife. But once the trip was over and the coaches returned to the school on Monday afternoon - the little boy was nowhere to be found. After the school realised he was not on any of the vehicles, his frantic mother Amanda, 28, and a group of teachers rushed back to the park where Owen had luckily been found by a security guard still playing in the safari park's children's area. Council chiefs have now launched an investigation into the blunder. But Owen's grandmother, Sandra McQueen, 51, from Dunfermline, said her family demanded 'answers from the school'. She said: 'There were about 300 kids from the school on the trip to the safari park and other mums have said it was a bit of a shambles. 'When Amanda went to pick him up from nursery at 3pm and she was told that she had to wait for the rest of the buses to arrive because Owen wasn't back yet. 'Then one of the teachers said to her "we don't know where Owen is". All the buses were in but they didn't have any clue where he was.' Mrs McQueen said: 'I asked if they had phoned the police and they said 'No', so I told her that I wanted the police involved. 'Four of the teachers got into a car and Amanda got into another one with another teacher and her husband and they drove to the safari park. 'One of Amanda's friends phoned her on the way and said that she had spoken to the park but that no one else at that point had phoned about it. 'The safari park sent out their security to look for him and he was found about 3.30pm by the security guard. 'We're not sure where exactly he was found, but Owen said he was in a play park and the guard had come over to him and asked his name. After that he was taken to their restaurant. 'He'd been missing since the busses left at 1.15pm and no one had any idea where he was. 'Amanda was so relieved. My heart sunk when she first called. He's her five-year-old boy. Anything could've happened to him there, it's full of wild animals.' Owen was left behind at Blair Drummond safari park by bungling school staff - who only noticed when they arrived back at the nursery an hour later (stock picture) A group of 300 children - accompanied by 70 adults - enjoyed a day out at Blair Drummond, near Stirling, which houses lion and tiger enclosures among its attractions (stock picture) Council officials visited the family on Tuesday to apologise, and promised an investigation would be launched. Mrs McQueen added: 'They said they had contacted the Care Commission and there would be an inquiry in to it, but when we phoned the Care Commission on Wednesday, they said they'd not heard anything about it. 'We're very angry and we want answers about what happened and why the teachers never did a head count or took a register. RELATED ARTICLES

Article.title: Was Winston Churchill the lovechild of the King of Serbia? Book makes extraordinary claims that British hero's mother had secret relationship with Balkan prince
Article.Description: Author Dragoslava Koprivica claims the former Prime Minister's mother had a relationship with Milan Obrenovic before he went on to rule the Balkan state.
Article.MainBody: Was Winston Churchill the lovechild of the King of Serbia? Book makes extraordinary claims that British hero's mother had secret relationship with Balkan prince Author claims Lady Churchill met Milan Obrenovic while studying in Paris Dragoslava Koprivica claimsLady Churchill's sister wrote about their love She claims Churchill tried to cover up romance by altering mother's diary Koprivica even claims that Joseph Stalin may have known about romance Published: 16:19 GMT, 28 May 2015 | Updated: 16:34 GMT, 28 May 2015 95 shares comments Winston Churchill was the illegitimate son of the King of Serbia, a new book claims. Author Dragoslava Koprivica claims the former British Prime Minister's mother had a secret relationship with Milan Obrenovic before he went on to rule the Balkan state. She also alleges that Churchill tried to cover up the romance by altering his mother's diaries. In her book King Milan and Lady Churchill, Koprivica, 44, says she spentyears studying archives across Europe, gathering information on Jeanette Jerome, who became Lady Randolph Churchill when she married Churchill's father Randolph in 1874. Winston Churchill (left) was the lovechild of Milan Obrenovic (right) before he become the King of Serbia, according to a book byDragoslava Koprivica who says she spent years studying records across Europe Koprivica claims her sources included the diary of one of the Lady Churchill's sisters which reportedly described her love for Milan Obrenovic. During her research, Koprivica also found letters from the Obrenovic family that reportedly made it clear they knew about this love. She says Milan Obrenovic and Lady Churchill met in Paris in 1867 while they were studying and that she left diaries which Churchill allegedly altered to hide the romance. RELATED ARTICLES Share this article Share She said: 'After his mother's death Churchill took her diary and removed from it all the pages where her love relationship with Obrenovic was described. 'There are many gaps in the biographies about Churchill's family about the time when Lady Churchill was married and conceived. Koprivica alleges that Churchill removed pages from the diary of his motherJeanette Jerome (left), who became Lady Randolph Churchill when she married Churchill's father Randolph (right) 'There is also clear evidence that Churchill was interfering with his and his mother biographies and in the relevant years removed everything that he didn't like.' According to Koprivica, the memoirs, diaries and letters show that her son was in fact the child of the Serbian king Milan Obrenovic (1854-1901), who was notoriously unfaithful to his wife Presenting her book in the north Serbian town of Gornji Milanovac, she said: 'I used hundreds of books and details from different archives to complete the book in three years.' She added that Joseph Stalin probably knew of the relationship. Lady Churchill pictured with her sons Winston (right) and John circa 1885 She said one of the compelling pieces of evidence was at the Yalta Conference in 1945 when Churchill met Stalin and the US president Roosevelt to decide upon the fate of post-war Europe. Churchill was apparently strongly against the idea of a monarchy prevailing in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia at the Yalta Conference. Koprivica used some records by Stalin in which he wrote that both him and Roosevelt were surprised by Churchill's support for the Communists of Yugoslavia. Because of Churchill's policy, Stalin humorously asked (paraphrasing) 'Did one of the Serbian monarchs personally step on your toe?' Share or comment on this article 95

Article.Description: Jodie Eastwood, from Herne Bay in Kent, fears her toddler could have easily choked or cut his mouth open on the sharp tacks if she hadn't noticed them. She claimed it could even ended in tragedy.
Article.MainBody: 'She said "mum, you'd never guess what I've just found in a loaf of bread".'I thought she was going to say a mouse or a spider, but I never would'vethought she was going to tell me she'd found metal nails. 'At that age, toddlers eat anything, so even if she wasn't making him asandwich, he may have reached up for a slice of bread unknowingly. It's truly terrifying.' She added: 'If she hadn't spotted it, he could've bitten into it and cut hismouth open, he could've choked or swallowed it and it's horrible to say, butit could have been fatal.' Article.title: Leeds Jewish nursing home applies for late licence to host bar mitzvahs
Article.Description: Jo Crossland, chief operating officer of Donisthorpe Hall in Leeds, insists the application is to allow families to celebrate bar mitzvahs, adding that she only wants to reinstate an old similar licence.
Article.MainBody: comments Defence: Jo Crossland, chief operating officer of Donisthorpe Hall in Leeds, insists the application is to allow families to celebrate bar mitzvahs A Jewish nursing home has applied for a late licence to host 'alcohol-fuelled' bar mitzvahs - a move branded by angry neighbours as dangerous. Donisthorpe Hall is hoping for a licence from Leeds City Council that would allow alcohol to be supplied on evenings from Saturday to Thursday and music played every night. However neighbours have described the idea as inappropriate, warning that it would destroy the calm enjoyed by local residents - with another saying: This is a nursing home, not an entertainment venue. But Jo Crossland, the homes chief operating officer, insists the application is to allow families to celebrate bar mitzvahs, adding that she only wants to reinstate an old similar licence. Noise nuisance and anti-social behaviour are among the concerns cited in papers to be considered by the councils licensing sub-committee next Tuesday. One objector wrote: I believe it is inappropriate and potentially dangerous to allow alcohol to be sold in a building dedicated to the care of elderly people. Another said: This is a nursing home, not an entertainment venue... residents are on high medication so alcohol until 11pm would not be advised. Ms Crossland said the application merely sought to reinstate a previous licence which had lapsed when her predecessor left last year. She said: We have a function room and the functions we hold there are family parties, bar mitzvahs, 90th birthdays and that sort of thing. We have a lot of elderly residents and it means they can have parties on site. We probably hold no more than six to eight functions a year and some of them are little more than tea parties. Looks after 182 residents: Donisthorpe Hall (above) is a Jewish residential and nursing home with 230 staff Donisthorpe Hall is a Jewish residential and nursing home with 230 staff, which looks after 182 residents in nursing, residential care and specialist dementia care units. According to its website the accommodation and facilities can be favourably compared to that of a quality hotel. RELATED ARTICLES

Article.title: Starving Staffie Coco was so hungry it ate a bean bag after cruel owner left it while she went on holiday
Article.Description: Anita Bali, 31, shut her Staffordshire bull terrier in the garden of her home in Slough, Berkshire, to endure hot weather while she went on holiday. The dog was so hungry it ate stuffing from a bean bag.
Article.MainBody: Share 289 shares It is believed Ms Bali had gone on holiday for around three weeks but it is unclear where she went. The dog was rescued a few days into her trip. Animal welfare officers found the dog in a filthy garden full of junk, including broken toys, odd shoes, a mop and empty water bowls. Ms Bali insisted she had asked a friend to go in and feed Coco throughout June 2014, but no evidence could be found to back up her claim. She admitted one count of animal cruelty when she appeared at Reading Magistrates' Court and was ordered to do 80 hours community service. Living in squalor: Animal welfare officers found the dog in a filthy garden full of junk (pictured), including broken toys, odd shoes, a mop and empty water bowls. Worried neighbours had thrown food and water over the fence Ms Bali admitted one count of animal cruelty when she appeared at Reading Magistrates' Court (pictured) and was ordered to do 80 hours community service.She was banned from keeping animals for 10 years She was banned from keeping animals for 10 years and told to pay 600 costs, plus a 60 victim surcharge. Ian Blake, neighbourhood enforcement manager, said: 'Thankfully Coco was none the worse for wear, thanks to the neighbours who fed and watered her. 'But she was clearly very distressed and it's hard to imagine what she went through in those few days.' Coco was later rehomed and is living happily with another family. Councillor Sohail Munawar, from Slough Borough Council, said: 'It's beyond me how anyone could leave their pet at home alone while they go off on holiday. Stephen Burns, 18, Connor Clift, 18, and a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named due to his age, attacked Darren Ewers 'like out of control wild dogs' in an unprovoked attack in December last year The party spilled into the street where the gang jumped in front of a taxi and punched the driver as he made attempts to reason with the boys. Mr Sithambaranathan had parked his BMW on the road and was taking 4,000 of takings to the post office when a red Audi A4 pulled up next to his car The Audi can be seen on CCTV footage as it pulls up alongside MrSithambaranathan's silver car Three yobs then sprinted round the corner and repeatedly punched MrSithambaranathan in the head After snatching the money, the gang then jumped into the Audi and sped off, leaving Mr Sithambaranathan suffering head and neck injuries. If they ask for the money then you know they've come for the money. 'I was really worried about my son. I didn't know, where is he?! I thought they were going to take the car as well because he is inside it. 'It was a very frightening moment. I believe it's not only me. They are out there. It will happen to somebody else as well.' Police today released shocking footage of the raid, showing how the hooded thugs wearing ski masks bundled Mr Sithambaranathan to the floor, leaving him fearing for his life Another gang member jumped out of the Audi and sprayed a fire extinguisher at MrSithambaranathan The getaway car had false number plates with the registration number A61 HBH. 'Unfortunately those involved had their faces covered and the red Audi A4 was on false plates. 'We hope that someone who was in the area that Saturday morning may remember seeing the car, seeing it being dumped somewhere or maybe spotting the occupants changing over number plates later that day. 'We urge anyone who has any information to contact us as soon as possible to help identify those involved.' Following a BBC Crimewatch appeal on Tuesday night, a spokeswoman for West Midlands Police said: 'We have received a number of calls about the suspect and the vehicle, and we are in the process of following up these positive lines of inquiry.' Article.title: City trader accused of Libor-rigging fraud 'offered broker $100,000 for help rigging rates'
Article.Description: Southwark Crown Court today heard evidence from telephone calls made in 2008 in which Tom Hayes (pictured) is alleged to have offered a broker $100,000 to keep Libor rates low.
Article.MainBody: City trader accused of Libor-rigging fraud 'offered broker $100,000 for help rigging rates' Tom Hayes is said to have dangled prospect of 'humongous deal' to broker Court heard he offered $100,000 to keep Libor 'as low as possible' Hayes said to be the 'ringmaster' in trillions of pounds of rate fixing fraud Denies eight counts of conspiracy to defraud between 2006 and 2010 In 2008, UBS bosses exchanged emails raving about his performance, describing his behaviour as 'utterly professionally' By Euan Mclelland For Mailonline Published: 12:36 GMT, 28 May 2015 | Updated: 14:51 GMT, 28 May 2015 A City trader offered a broker a 'humongous deal' as he tried to manipulate a key interest rate which is behind trillions of dollars worth of financial deals, a court has heard. Tom Hayes, 35, promised to pay his contact up to $100,000 if he kept the Libor rate 'as low as possible', jurors at Southwark Crown Court in London were today told. Prosecutors in his trial claim that Hayes, a former UBS and Citigroup trader, was motivated by 'greed' and acted as the 'ringmaster' in an enormous fraud to rig the benchmark interest rate used for interbank lending. Hayes arriving at Southwark Crown Court on Thursday alongside wife Sarah. It was today alleged that he offered a broker a 'humongous deal' as he tried to manipulate the interest rate at which banks lend to one another RELATED ARTICLES Share this article Share The court heard that, in a telephone call in 2008, Hayes told a broker: 'I don't care right - just get me any f****** trade which pays you basically, mate. 'If you keep fixes unchanged, I'll do a humongous deal with you. 'If you keep it as low as possible, I can do that. 'I'll, of course, support and pay you...$50,000, $100,000, whatever you want, all right? 'I'm a man of my word.' Jurors were also told that Hayes exploded with anger when he felt brokers were not doing his bidding. The court was told that Hayes, in a 2008 phone call, offered a broker $100,000 to keep Libor low 'It is a disgrace I am livid,' he wrote in one message dated May 2009. 'I am missing out on everything today, no one is giving me any priority, I am going to pull the line...that was pathetic.' One contact assured him: 'I devote 100% of my time and effort into helping you make money.' In another message read to the court from the same year, Hayes moans some of his contacts are 'too busy planning trips to Marbella' to help him out, it was said. 'This is another occasion where Mr Hayes is clearly unhappy, it is basically I am really cross with what you guys have been doing, you are not getting me into trades,' said Mr Chawla. Hayes begged brokers to help him spin the Libor rates in his favour and then handed them kickback payments by setting up 'utterly pointless' deals, it was said. 'Wash trades' involved two banks striking a deal, and then putting through the same deal but reversing their positions. By mirroring each other, there was no risk to the trade so neither bank lost or gained cash. But the brokers still raked in substantial fees and Hayes used this method to send bribes to keep his contacts sweet, jurors were told. Mr Chawla said: 'There were 14 wash trades in all while Mr Hayes was at UBS and on which UBS paid brokerage, paid commission - they were nothing more than kickbacks or bribes to rewards his brokers.' Jurors were shown a spreadsheet showing UBS paid a total of 471,500 in brokerage fees for the pointless deals. Hayes also targeted a broker, described as an 'enthusiastic assistant', to help him manipulate the daily Libor rates. 'Low everything please mate,' Hayes wrote to the broker on February 25, 2009, on the Bloomberg chat system. WHAT IS THE LIBOR AND WHY DOES IT MATTER IF IT'S MANIPULATED? The Libor rate, or London Interbank Offered Rate, is an interest rate at which banks lend money to each other around the world. Rate rigging is when traders or brokers collude to set artificial rates, rather than genuine assessments of what the borrowing rates should be. Bankers are able to take out bets, or contracts, based on the way the rates will move. If they find a way to manipulate the rates, or persuade someone to manipulate them for them, then they are fixing the bet in their favour. This seriously undermines the integrity of the Libor financial system, on which global banks and financial institutions rely. British trader Tom Hayes is charged with eight counts of conspiring to defraud by 'dishonestly' manipulating the Libor interest rate. The Libor rate is linked to the cost of trillions of pounds worth of investments and trades. It is set in many different currencies Hayes is accused of fiddling the rate for Japanese yen. The charges carry a maximum jail term of ten years. 'Got ya,' replied the broker. 'If you get 3m [three month Libor rate] down you will get a decent deal from me tomorrow,' urged Hayes. In a further message Hayes tried to persuade his contact to push for the rates he wants. 'Alright well buy them lunch, do whatever you can do,' he wrote. 'Yeah, yeah...just making sure they told the stupid f*****g c***s, they sound like a right load of idiots these cash dealers,' replied his pal. In a message to another contact, Hayes wrote: 'I'm just trying to think who you might be able to f*****g lean on a bit today.' Mr Chawla said: 'Does that have the hallmark of honesty to it?' He added: 'That is the conspiracy at work...getting them to speak to their clients, their mates at the bank to move to mates rates in order to help Mr Hayes. 'In order to help his trading position and in return for that they put through these wash trades or bribes. 'Just putting it all together that is what it's about.' Hayes bragged to another broker he had made millions of dollars for UBS, the court heard. 'Touch wood had a good start, up 105m this year so far,' he boasted in April 2009. His contact replied: 'Good to hear. Christ. Last time we spoke you mentioned 60 million and I thought that was ridiculous.' Hayes even told him what his future position would be months down the line, despite Libor being set on a daily basis. Mukul Chawla QC, prosecuting, told the jury that Hayes was becoming an 'increasingly dominant force' within his market by May 2008, and he was approached by another bank, Goldman Sachs. 'He was offered quite a lot of money but UBS wanted to hold on to him,' the prosecutor told the court. The jury was shown an email dated June 24, 2008, from UBS's head of European trades, Sascha Prinz, to the investment bank's chief executive, Jerker Johansson, which described Hayes as one of his 'most talented traders in Tokyo'. 'Tom Hayes is being aggressively pursued by Goldman Sachs,' he wrote. 'They have offered Tom a larger role with significantly more responsibility, plus a $3.2million guarantee for 2009.' Hayes' bonus at UBS for 2007 was $1.25million, which was 'on the low side of his expectations', Mr Prinz added. Hayes wasarrested in December 2012 as part of a massive criminal inquiry into the scandal by the Serious Fraud Office. His trial at Southwark Crown Court is expected to last almost three months He went on: 'I don't believe in guarantees in managing my business...but I would like to make an exception in this case and offer Tom a target letter with a target of $2.5million for 2008. 'I believe that, in conjuction with some changes in responsibilities, it would convince him to stay at UBS. 'Throughout this whole process he has behaved utterly professionally.' Hayes was sent a letter from UBS the next day which offered him target-related pay for 2008 of 269 million yen, or 1.29 million, the court heard. Mr Chawla told the jury: 'Because of the financial crisis, Mr Hayes didn't receive anything like that but that was what he was promised, just under 1.3 million for that year.' The jury has previously been told that Hayes left UBS in September 2008, and joined American bank Citigroup, where he earned around 3.5 million for just nine months' work in 2009. Hayes, of Fleet, Hampshire, denies eight counts of conspiracy to defraud over a period from 2006 to 2010. Share or comment on this article MOST WATCHED NEWS VIDEOS

Article.title: Chernobyl survivor returns to Pripyat to take poignant self-portraits
Article.Description: Alina Rudya was just one when her parents fled her hometown of Pripyat in Ukraine in the wake of the meltdown at the power plant, where her father worked, in 1986.
Article.MainBody: Alex Salmond appeared to be very vocal as the Queen exits Alina takes a self-portrait in her old apartment in the Ukrainian town of Pripyat which she escaped as a baby after the disaster. She decided to pose nude to show 'where my life basically started over because of the disaster, so I am both vulnerable and exposed at the same time' Poignant reminder: When Rudya visited her old apartment, she found this photograph of her and her mother on the floor after all these years Reflection: Alina gazes out of the window of her family's apartment over the wasteland left behind when the town was abandoned 30 years ago She added: 'This is our apartment, number 24, at Lenin Street. Many people ask me why I am nude, and my answer is that I wanted to show the place I came from, where my life basically started over because of the disaster, so I am both vulnerable and exposed at the same time.' Her father, Constantine, was working as an engineer at the plant on the night of the accident. She said: 'He was there when the whole thing happened and he couldn't leave his shift, even though just next door the tragedy was happening. 'His friends were working on the fourth reactor, which exploded and some of them died back in 1986, some others are still alive and I hope to photograph them for the project.' The second part of her project will once again see her return through the forbidden zone to Pripyat to share stories of other people whose lives were changed by the disaster. Turning back the clock: The 30-year-old, who now lives in Berlin, first returned to the town in 2012 and is now looking to make another visit to complete her project to mark the 30th anniversary of the Chernobyl catastrophe Eerie: Alina took this ghostly image of herself in an area outside her family's old home.The first part of the project, called Prypyat

Article.title: SNP's floral tribute to Scotland is revealed to be a rose grown in ETHIOPIA
Article.Description: Scots Nats MPs had to make to do with a white rose from Ethiopia, instead of the native Scottish flower they were meant to be paying tribute to when they took their seats in Westminster yesterday.
Article.MainBody: comments Scotland's new army of nationalist MPs made a dramatic show of their patriotism yesterday - by adorning themselves with a special floral buttonhole for the state opening of Parliament. But the stunt - in honour of the patriotic poem 'Little White Rose of Scotland' - backfired today after it emerged the flower chosen was actually an ordinary rose grown in Africa and exported around the world. The SNP this morning attempted to brush off the embarrassing revelation - insisting they 'did not care' where the flowers came from. Scroll down for video Former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond and all of the SNP's 56 MPs wore white roses to take their seats in Parliament yesterday Scottish National MPs wore a ordinary florists' rose (pictured left) yesterday - and not the Scottish White Rose (pictured right) 'THE WHITE ROSE OF SCOTLAND' Scottish poet Hugh MacDiarmid (pictured) SNP MPs and its members of the Scottish Parliament have made a tradition of wearing the floral button hole at all Westminster and Holyrood parliament openings. The flower was made famous by Scottish poet Hugh MacDiarmid in 'The Little White Rose of Scotland'. The poem reads: 'The rose of all the world is not for me 'I want for my part 'Only the little white rose of Scotland 'That smells sharp and sweet - and breaks the heart.' But the claim appears to undermine the opening line of Hugh MacDiarmid's famous poem, which the flowers were supposed to honour. The poem starts:The rose of all the world is not for me.' MacDiarmond says all he wants is the little white rose of Scotland which smells sharp and sweet and breaks the heart. All 56 of the Scottish National MPs adorned themselves with the dazzling white rose in tribute to the poem as they arrived in Westminster for the Queen's Speech yesterday morning. But it emerged this morning that the rose chosen by the SNP - at a florists in Westminster - was not the Scottish variety glorified by MacDiarmid, but an ordinary florists rose grown mainly in East Africa. The Royal Horticultural Society today confirmed the flower worn by the SNP MPs was not the Scottish rose. The organisation's chief horticulturalist Guy Barter told MailOnline: 'The Scottish white rose is a very pretty little thing. But they are seldom, if ever, offered by florists. 'The SNP appear to be wearing white florists roses. Florists roses are a commercial form of rose bred to produce long-stemmed neat roses for button holes and arrangements. He said the florists rose was actually derived from English tea roses about 50 years ago. But he said: It is now a specialist branch of rose breeding with little in common with garden tea roses. 'Rose cut flower production is dominated by Kenya, Columbia, Israel and Ethiopia, and to the best of my knowledge none are now grown in Britain and few even in Holland which is the centre of breeding cut flower roses. He added: 'The tea-rose has a long lineage of Asian and European species and as the hybrid tea rose was first breed in France. 'It has been and still is extensively bred in the UK, USA, France and Germany. It is not especially English, and the world register of rose varieties is held by the American Rose Society.' An SNP source this morning insisted said they had never claimed the flower was an actual Scottish rose. Its insignificant where the rose comes from. It symbolises the white rose in the poem, the source said. Alex Salmond appears with 'Little White Rose Of Scotland'... Mhairi Black MP walks with her SNP colleagues through the members lobby of the House of Commons during the State Opening of Parliament today Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was pictured in the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh following yesterday's Queen's Speech in Westminster The partys MPs bought the roses for 2 each from a florist in Westminster. The source added: We just asked for white roses. We dont care if its an English rose or not. SNP MPs and its members of the Scottish Parliament have made a tradition of wearing the floral button hole at all Westminster and Holyrood parliament openings. The flower was made famous by MacDiarmid in 'The Little White Rose of Scotland'. The poem reads: The rose of all the world is not for me; I want for my part; Only the little white rose of Scotland; That smells sharp and sweet - and breaks the heart.' AN EXPERT VIEW: THE SCOTTISH ROSE IS 'A PRETTY LITTLE THING' BUT SELDOM IF EVER AVAILABLE TO BUY IN BRITAIN Guy Barter, of the Royal Horticultural Society, confirmed the flower worn by the SNP MPs was not the Scottish rose: 'The Scottish white rose is a very pretty little thing. They are seldom if ever offered by florists. 'The SNP appear to be wearing white florists roses. Florists roses are a commercial form of rose bred to produce long-stemmed neat roses for button holes and arrangements. 'The florists rose was derived from tea roses about 50 years ago but is now a specialist branch of rose breeding with little in common with garden tea roses. 'Rose cut flower production is dominated by Kenya, Columbia, Israel and Ethiopia, and to the best of my knowledge none are now grown in Britain and few even in Holland which is the centre of breeding cut flower roses. 'The tea-rose has a long lineage of Asian and European species and as the hybrid tea rose was first breed in France. 'It has been and still is extensively bred in the UK, USA, France and Germany. It is not especially English, and the world register of rose varieties is held by the American Rose Society.' Share or comment on this article 529

Article.title: Lincoln woman exhumed because pathologist got the cause of death WRONG
Article.Description: The family of tragic Gemma Wilks' from Lincoln, pictured, looked on in horror during her exhumation when they saw that the 23-year-old's coffin had caved in while ti was being exhumed because of errors in her first post mortem.
Article.MainBody: Share this article Share An inquest heard the coffin was dug up in September last year at 3am from its site at Newport Cemetery in Lincoln. During the exhumation, Ms Wilks' family looked on in absolute horror when she saw the coffin had collapsed inwards. The trauma of the revelation made her miss work for the next three months due to stress. A second post-mortem was then conducted by Home Office pathologist Professor Guy Rutty who found that she died of an overdose of prescribed medication. An inquest at Lincoln Cathedral Centre heard the exhumation was extremely rare. The pathologist said that her gall bladder was normal, even though it had been removed eight years earlier Mrs Wilks, from near Bracebridge, Lincoln, said: 'Ill never forget the exhumation. It was terrible. 'The coroner said it was the only one hed ever ordered in more than 20 years. 'It took nearly four hours and there were people there from all over the world because it was so rare. 'Gemma had a coffin which had collapsed in on her. I had to turn away at that point and I had three months off work because it was so horrible. 'It was an absolutely awful situation because the second funeral was within days of the exhumation, so we had to bury her without her heart. 'Because Dr Imrad Soomros cause of death said heart failure we were issued with an interim death certificate and given the go-ahead for her funeral. 'Its only because I noticed inconsistencies that I questioned the whole process. 'Gemma could be warm and generous, even though she clearly had many issues and would often cut herself quite badly, requiring hospital treatment.' The inquest heard that Ms Wilks had lived in agony for 11 years after a foot operation as a 12-year-old led to constant pain, depression, self-harm and five suicide attempts. Ms Wilks' mother Carrie, right, pictured with grand mother Jennifer James, left, noticed the mistake over the gall bladder and alerted authorities who ordered that her daughter's body should be exhumed from her grave Ms Wilks' family looked on in horror as they saw that the lid of the coffin had caved in She had been diagnosed with an emotional personality disorder and was taking six different drugs for pain management and depression. Professor Rutty was brought in by Senior Central Lincolnshire Coroner Stuart Fisher to investigate what the hearing was told were 'inconsistencies' he found in the first autopsy. He told the hearing: 'Considering the medical history of an individual with a history of self-inflicted injuries, attempted suicides and circumstances suggesting an overdose, it would be most unusual to have issued a natural cause of death.' Mr Fisher said that the General Medical Council had contacted him to ask for a report on the inquest proceedings because it was investigating Dr Soomros conduct in carrying out the first post-mortem. Ms Wilks' father Dean Pearce, 46, said: 'At the end of the day, weve had to bury our only child twice.' Grandmother Jennifer James said: 'She was a normal little girl until she was 12, then she had the foot operation after the pain from her bones swelling became so intense. 'Her care was as chaotic as her life. 'Gemma could be totally exasperating because of her personality disorder, missing appointments and regularly misusing her medication. 'Her life had been one of a cheerful child who had lots of friends. Eleven years later, we watched her grave being opened.' The hearing continues. Article.title: Touching moment little boy with cerebral palsy walks for the first time
Article.Description: Archie Garthwaite (with twin Harley), from Hartlepool, was born at just 23 weeks with cerebral palsy. His condition meant that the muscles in his legs have no strength. Thanks to physio, he's gaining trength.
Article.MainBody:
Share 2.1k shares Although Botox treatment is now becoming more common for some cerebral palsy patients, not all NHS Trusts will fund it and there are often long waiting lists for treatment. Archie was diagnosed with cerebral palsy in June last year. The condition, which causes movement and co-ordination problems, is caused by a problem in the parts of the brain responsible for controlling muscles, This followed a series of complications when he and his brother were born 17 weeks early, and became the most premature twins ever to survive in the UK at that time. They were delivered at just 23 weeks, on June 13 and 14, 2012, weighing just 1lb 4oz and 1lb 6oz much less than the UK average of 7lb 8oz. 'When they were born we asked the doctors to just give them a chance and it is just amazing to think that they did that,' Mrs Kennedy said. 'I was adamant they were going to die, but Billy stood by me and stayed positive. Archie and Harley, from Hartlepool, Cleveland, had an unprecedented fight for survival after being born just 23 weeks into their mother's pregnancy. 'Harley was sent to Newcastle hospital while Archie was still at North Tees and that was really difficult for us.' The boys both had holes in their tiny hearts and at just two weeks old Archie had to undergo open heart surgery, with his brother Harley following two weeks later. Medics also operated to correct bowel problems, performed laser treatment on their underdeveloped eyes, and put them on ventilators and oxygen to help them to breathe. But despite the odds, the pair survived and while Harley has eyesight and lung problems, he can walk and talk like any normal toddler. Both boys were born with holes in their hearts and at just two weeks old, Archie (pictured) underwent open heart surgery Archie's cerebral palsy means his muscles don't work as well, and he can't talk as well as his brother. But regular physiotherapy, and Botox injections has seen him stand up alone and now it is hoped he will be able to walk like his brother. And despite their troubles the twins have managed to find a touch of notoriety in the local community. Mrs Kennedy said: 'When we go out shopping all the old ladies stop and say 'oh look it's the little twins from the papers'. 'It is amazing to think that because I don't look at them as the smallest twins. 'They are both incredible and they are both as strong as little oxen. 'It is incredible they have come this far but they have just bounced off each other.

Article.title: MBE poppy seller like Olive Cooke is also plagued by 'deplorable' charities
Article.Description: Dionis MacNair, 85, (pictured) from Burley, Hampshire, started selling poppies door-to-door with her mother Ruth when she was just seven years old.
Article.MainBody: The opening of the inquest into her death last week heard she had ' long term issues with periodic depression', and it has been reported that she had become stressed by the endless cold calls and begging letters she was receiving every month from charities. Ms MacNair today described the charities as 'deplorable' and slammed their treatment of grandmother-of-four Mrs Cooke, who lived in the Fishponds area of Bristol, as 'appalling'. Ms MacNair, pictured left aged ten, started selling poppies with her mother when she was just seven, and last week she was honoured by the Royal British Legion for her 78-years of service to the charity (right) The former secretary also said the worst offenders should be 'named and shamed'. 'I think it is deplorable that they bothered her to such an extent, and so many of them,' said Ms MacNair, who has never married 'It to be cutting your nose off to spite your face. 'I think [what they did to Mrs Cooke] it was appalling. I think everybody does. 'The charities never leave you alone. I've experienced that - I think everyone has. 'They pass your details on to everyone else. It is deplorable. It has been reported that Mrs Cooke had become stressed by the endless cold calls and begging letters she was receiving every month from charities Ms MacNair says she has experience of charities passing 'your details to everyone else', and says she will put the phone down on cold callers 'I just put the phone down and say I don't want to talk, but I am fairly thick-skinned and a lot of people aren't and I'm sure she did find it hard.' She added: ' I think [the cold calling] is taking advantage of the vulnerable in the way that should never happen, certainly not from charities and especially not to dedicated people like her. 'I think the worst offenders should be named - I say name them all and say absolutely everybody thinks this is deplorable, you're killing your own charity. 'People aren't going to help you if they continue doing this sort of thing.' Mrs Cooke's family have insisted that - while the letters and phone calls were intrusive and a nuisance - the charities were not to blame for her death. Ms MacNair's mother Ruth, pictured on her wedding day to naval officer Ian, started supporting the British Legion after it was launched in 1921 Ms MacNair started going out with her mother to raise money as she grew up in Alverstoke, Hampshire Ms MacNair's mother Ruth, an artist and wife of a naval officer, started supporting the British Legion after it was launched in 1921. She started going out with her mother to raise money as she grew up in Alverstoke, Hampshire. She recalled: ' We had only just moved in and my mother took me around poppy selling. 'It was a very good way of meeting the neighbours and as a result we had a wonderful free childhood without realising that people were keeping an eye on us. Ms MacNair's father Ian (pictured) served in the Royal Navy during the Second World War 'I used to rattle the tin and she used to carry the tray. 'I did it for years and years and then eventually took over from her.' The family moved again to Malta and Gibraltar, where Dionis' father Ian served in the Royal Navy during the war before they returned to Burley. Ms MacNair was presented with an award and certificate by Deputy Lieutenant of Hampshire Brigadier David Harrison recognising her work for the Legion. She was the first woman to be elected as a New Forest Verderer - overseeing the management of the area - and was awarded an MBE in 2010 for her services to the region. Mrs Cooke started selling poppies in 1938 when she was just 16 after her father served in Gallipoli during the First World War. She devoted herself fully to the charity after husband Leslie Hussey-Yeo, a sailor in the Royal Navy, was killed in Italy in 1943, leaving her a war widow at the age of 21. The great-grandmother dedicated almost eight decades to raising thousands of pounds, selling an estimated 30,000 poppies in 76 years, andwas a familiar face in Bristol and stood in the doorway of the city's cathedral every year in the lead-up to Remembrance Day. It is claimed the former postwoman 'lost faith in people' two months before her death when 250 in cash she sent to a relative went missing in the post. She was also dealing with constant phone calls and up to 260 begging letters a month from charities pestering her for cash. Mrs Cooke was found dead on a cliff face overlooking Clifton Suspension Bridge after she was spotted jumping from a ledge on May 6,two days before the anniversary of VE Day. Ms MacNair said: 'I think so many of the big charities spend an awful lot on raising money, rather than on actually giving it to the charity. 'When I was a secretary of a charity many years ago we got a thing from the Charity Commission saying they would look very unfavourably on charities who spend more than six per cent on administration. Some of these charity are spending 60 per cent. 'That's not what people give there money for. 'They want their money to go to the cause.' Share or comment on this article 73

Article.Description: Remarkable footage of the big cat struggling to stay afloat and seeking refuge on the bloated carcass was captured by two bemused tourists visiting the Sabi River in Kruger National Park, South Africa.
Article.MainBody: comments A lion has been caught on camera using a hippo carcass as a makeshift life raft - after nearly drowning in an attempt to cross a swollen river to eat it. Remarkable footage of the big cat struggling to stay afloat and seeking refuge on the bloated carcass was captured by two tourists visiting the Sabi River in Kruger National Park, South Africa. Filmed by French tourists Denis and Valerie Wiest late last year, the lion was caught in a spot of bother after spying what it thought was a free lunch in the river. The lion was seen chewing on the hippo carcass in the middle of the surging river in South Africa But the slippery hippo remains saw the lion tumble into the swollen river head first The currently quickly started pulling it downstream and it began frantically paddling towards its only refuge The lion managed to reach the carcass once again and it climbed back on top of it to avoid the rushing water Mr Wiest confirmed that after misjudging the strong current, the big cat ended up using his meal as refuge. As an MP I will always use public transport and I do not want to live in a society when politicos don't' Protesters holding placards can be seen in the reflection of the police van taking Mr Carswell to safety Demonstrations: Mr Carswell, left, stands next to anti-austerity protesters in Westminster earlier today Flanked: Mr Carswell, Ukip's only MP, is taken to a waiting police van by a number of officers It came as police chased protesters through the streets around Parliament and Whitehall. Meanwhile, one group staged a sit-in protest near Trafalgar Square, bringing traffic to a standstill. Police confirmed that at least three people were arrested during the unrest in Westminster today. One protester, who did not want to be named, described how Douglas Carswell, Ukip's only MP, was surrounded by demonstrators and doused in water before being bundled to safety by police. He said: 'Douglas Carswell was in St James' Tube, someone spotted him and everyone rushed over. 'Everyone was chanting and he was stuck. The police had to push through the crowd and he got a bottle of water thrown over him. Then police put him in a van and he was driven away.' Andy Dent, 39, who runs a joinery business and lives in Surrey, said: 'The Tories give tax cuts for the rich, they want to bring back fox hunting - they are trying to turn this country back into Victorian England. 'There are people out there who can't stand up for themselves, but that's what Britain is supposed to be about - helping the underdog and doing the right thing. 'We are going to see more protests when we see what the Tories do when they don't have the Lib Dems holding them back.' 'Shaken': Taking to Twitter later, the MP said that he was 'fine' and would 'always use public transport' The scenes (above) came as police chased protesters through the streets around Parliament and Whitehall Speaking afterwards, Mr Carswell said: 'I mean this was a lynch mob on the streets of London' Among those held by police was a man wanted in connection with an earlier anti-austerity demo outside Downing Street the day after the General Election results were confirmed. A Scotland Yard spokesman said: 'A 45-year-old man, wanted on suspicion of violent disorder in Whitehall on May 9th, was arrested. 'A 17-year-old youth was arrested on suspicion of assault on police during today's demonstration. 'A man was arrested on suspicion of violent disorder and possession of an offensive weapon during today's demonstration. 'All were taken to a central London police station where they remain in custody.' Share or comment on this article 756

Article.title: Nicola Sturgeon threatens backlash unless Scots spared cuts
Article.Description: Nicola Sturgeon says she will fight to 'lessen' budget cuts in Scotland, despite a report revealing the average Scot already has £1,600 more taxpayers’ cash spent on them than the typical Englishman.
Article.MainBody: Share 3.2k shares She said: I think if David Cameron is serious about listening to people right across the UK, then he will want to take notice of how people in Scotland voted because it was him during the referendum on independence last year who said that Scotland should vote to stay in the UK and its voice would be listened to as part of the UK. She added: If the UK Government sticks to its current proposals, we will argue for ways in which the impact on Scotland can be lessened. A generous funding formula means that Scots have benefited for years from much higher public spending than the English. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon outlines Scottish Business Pledge The First Minister - pictured with the Scottish championship trophy Tuesday - said she would demand that the impact of the government's austerity drive should be 'lessened' north of the border The gap, which stood at 1,496 per head in 2010, had widened to 1,597 per head four years later. Spending has fallen in both nations, but has dropped further and faster in England. 'The SNP won the election in Scotland fairly decisively on the basis of a pledge to argue the anti-austerity case, so that is what we will do', Sturgeon said Conservative MP David Nuttall said Scotlands decision last year to vote to remain part of the UK meant it could have no argument with the Governments legitimacy. The Bury North MP accused Miss Sturgeon of trying to whip up anti-Scottish sentiment in England by emphasising the gulf in spending. He added: The SNP need to recognise they lost the referendum and are in opposition. When it came to the decision about whether Scotland should remain in the UK, the majority of people said they wanted to. Part of that deal is accepting the winner of the General Election forms the Government of the entire UK. The SNP want to stir up anti-Scottish sentiment in England because they think it helps their cause. However, in a significant shift, Miss Sturgeon said she now backs the Governments Charter for Budget Responsibility, which sets targets for tackling the deficit. During the election campaign she had said Labours support for it was equivalent to signing up to the Tories plans for 30billion in cuts. n Powers for Scotland to set its own income tax levels will be fast-tracked today in the Queens Speech. The move could mean those north of the border pay less in income tax than the English, Welsh or Northern Irish. Scottish Secretary David Mundell said the law will be rushed through by next February.
